content: The "Sangre de Cristo National Heritage Area Act" establishes the Sangre de Cristo National Heritage Area, with defined terms such as Heritage Area, management entity, management plan, map, Secretary, and State. The Sangre de Cristo National Heritage Area is established in the State, encompassing specific counties and wildlife refuges. A map of the area will be included in the management plan and available for public inspection. The management entity will be the Sangre de Cristo National Heritage Area Board of Directors, with membership requirements for a diverse representation. The Sangre de Cristo National Heritage Area Board of Directors will include representatives from various individuals, agencies, organizations, and governments involved in the planning and development of the Heritage Area before the enactment of the Act. The administration of the Sangre de Cristo National Heritage Area will be overseen by a Board of Directors consisting of representatives from various entities involved in its planning and development. The Secretary, through the management entity, may use funds to make grants, enter agreements, hire staff with expertise, obtain money or services, contract for goods or services, and catalyze other activities for the management plan of the Sangre de Cristo National Heritage Area. The management entity for the Heritage Area will be a catalyst for activities that align with the approved management plan, including assisting local government and organizations with programs, exhibits, and recreational opportunities. The management entity for the Heritage Area will promote public awareness, protect historic sites, ensure clear signage, and foster partnerships to further the Heritage Area's goals. It will also consider the interests of diverse stakeholders in the area. The management entity in the Heritage Area will assist businesses, organizations, and individuals in preparing and implementing the management plan. They will hold public meetings semiannually, submit annual reports to the Secretary, and make all expenditure records available for audit. The management entity in the Heritage Area will assist in preparing and implementing the management plan, hold public meetings semiannually, submit annual reports to the Secretary, and make all expenditure records available for audit. Federal funds cannot be used to acquire real property, and the Federal share of costs for activities must be 50 percent. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The management entity must submit a proposed management plan for the Heritage Area within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The plan should integrate protection, enhancement, and interpretation of natural, cultural, historic, scenic, and recreational resources, consider State and local plans, and include an inventory of resources in the core area related to the Heritage Area themes. The proposed management plan for the Heritage Area should include comprehensive policies, strategies, and recommendations for conservation, funding, management, and development. It should also outline actions agreed upon by governments, private organizations, and individuals to protect the natural, historical, and cultural resources of the area. Additionally, the plan should include a program of implementation by the management entity, detailing actions to facilitate ongoing management. The curr_chunk focuses on actions for ongoing collaboration among partners, specific commitments for the first 5 years of operation, identification of funding sources, and recommendations for coordinating local, State, and Federal programs for the Heritage Area. The curr_chunk outlines the requirements for a management plan for the Heritage Area, including coordination, interpretive planning, and resource management strategies. Failure to submit the plan within 3 years will result in ineligibility for additional funding. Approval or disapproval of the plan is at the discretion of the Secretary. The Secretary, in consultation with the State, approves or disapproves the management plan within 180 days of receipt. Criteria for approval include diverse representation of interests in the Heritage Area and adequate public participation opportunities. If the Secretary disapproves the management plan, they must advise the management entity of the reasons, make recommendations for revisions, and receive any proposed revisions within 180 days. The Secretary must approve or disapprove any proposed revision or amendment to the management plan that makes a substantial change. The management entity cannot use federal funds for amendments until they are approved by the Secretary. SEC. 6. RELATIONSHIP TO OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES. In general, this Act does not affect the authority of Federal agencies to provide assistance under other laws. Federal agencies planning activities impacting the Heritage Area should consult with the Secretary and management entity. The Act does not modify laws authorizing Federal land management or limit the discretion of Federal land managers within the Heritage Area. SEC. 7. PRIVATE PROPERTY AND REGULATORY PROTECTIONS. The Act does not infringe on property owners' rights, including the right to refuse participation in Heritage Area activities, require public access to private property, change existing land use regulations, or claim water rights. It also prohibits any actions that diminish the State's authority to manage fish and wildlife within the Heritage Area or create liability for private property owners in case of injuries on their property. SEC. 8. EVALUATION; REPORT. The Secretary must conduct an evaluation of the Heritage Area's accomplishments and prepare a report before Federal funding ends. The evaluation will assess the management entity's progress in achieving the goals of the approved management plan, analyze investments, and review the management structure and partnerships. The Secretary will prepare a report with recommendations for the future role of the National Park Service in the Heritage Area, including an analysis of ways to reduce or eliminate Federal funding if reauthorization is recommended. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress with recommendations for the National Park Service's future role in the Heritage Area, including ways to reduce or eliminate Federal funding. Authorization of appropriations for this Act is set at $10,000,000, with a limit of $1,000,000 per fiscal year. The Secretary's authority to provide assistance under this Act will terminate 15 years after its enactment.
